summary: A letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York to Judge Paul A. Engelmayer, filed ex parte and under seal. It updates the court on the status of United States v. Noel, a related criminal case, and requests an extension of deadlines in a FOIA lawsuit brought by The New York Times for records related to Jeffrey Epstein. The letter indicates the government is finalizing deferred prosecution agreements for defendants in the Noel case.

persons.name: Paul A. Engelmayer
persons.context: The judge presiding over the FOIA case (The New York Times Co. v. Federal Bureau of Prisons) to whom this ex parte letter is addressed.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The deceased financier whose records are being sought by The New York Times in the underlying FOIA lawsuit.

events.title: Government Requests Extension in Epstein FOIA Case
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office files an ex parte, sealed letter with Judge Engelmayer requesting an extension of deadlines for document production in a FOIA lawsuit seeking Jeffrey Epstein-related records, citing ongoing efforts to finalize deferred prosecution agreements in the related criminal case United States v. Noel.

locations: 86 Chambers Street, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: The document is a sealed, ex parte communication from prosecutors to a judge, indicating sensitive negotiations in a related criminal case (U.S. v. Noel) are impacting the release of Jeffrey Epstein records.
The government reports it has preliminarily approved deferred prosecution agreements for both defendants in United States v. Noel and is awaiting Pretrial Services review.
The FOIA lawsuit, The New York Times Co. v. Federal Bureau of Prisons, seeks the release of certain records related to Jeffrey Epstein.
The government is attempting to expedite the resolution of the Noel case to clarify its reliance on a FOIA exemption (Exemption 7(A)) and conserve court resources.
The letter itself was filed under seal due to the 'sensitive and confidential nature' of the efforts to resolve the Noel prosecution.
